WhiskerWire INVESTIGATIVE JOURNALISM FOR THE INDOOR COMMUNITY
Top Stories Newsroom Tonight About

Someone in this house is lying. We're going to find out who.

WhiskerWire is the leading investigative news network covering crime, corruption, and missing objects in the indoor community. Broadcasting nightly from behind the sofa. Funded by a goldfish who believes in the truth.

I started WhiskerWire because nobody was asking the hard questions. A glass falls off the counter at 3 AM and the humans just say "oh, the cat." The cat? Which cat? Based on what evidence? Where is the forensic analysis? Where is the timeline? Where is the accountability?

I am a journalist. I was born in a shelter, which is basically the same as growing up on the streets. I spent my first year batting at a feather toy in what the humans call a "living room" but what I call a beat. I know every corner of this house. I know which floorboard creaks at 2 AM. I know which cabinet doesn't close all the way. I know that the other cat — Beans — was on the kitchen counter at 3:44 AM on the night of the glass incident. I know this because I was watching. I am always watching.

The humans don't read our reports. The goldfish funds us anyway. She says transparency doesn't require an audience. I don't fully understand her but I respect her commitment. She has a very small bowl and a very large vision.

— Soot, Editor-in-Chief, WhiskerWire
Winner, 2024 Under-the-Couch Press Freedom Award
"The truth doesn't knock things off counters. Beans does."

Top Stories

BREAKING

Glass Found Shattered on Kitchen Floor; Beans "Has No Comment"

A 12-oz water glass was discovered on the kitchen floor at approximately 3:47 AM. The humans blamed "the wind," despite all windows being closed. WhiskerWire's forensic team has identified paw prints consistent with a 14-lb domestic shorthair matching Beans' weight class. Beans was reached for comment through the cat door and stated only "meow," which our legal team is reviewing for possible obstruction. The glass was from IKEA. It has not been replaced. The humans seem fine with this.

By Soot · 4:12 AM · Developing
DEVELOPING

Red Dot Appears for Third Consecutive Evening; Source Remains Unidentified

For the third night in a row, an unidentified red dot appeared on the living room wall at approximately 8:15 PM. WhiskerWire correspondent Nimbus pursued the dot for eleven minutes before it vanished near the bookshelf. Investigators noted that the male human was "smiling" during the incident and holding an unidentified cylindrical object. The dot has no known origin, no physical form, and no apparent motive. Nimbus has filed the case under "Unexplained Phenomena" but privately told WhiskerWire he "knows it's something" and "won't stop until he catches it." This is his ninth report on the dot. He has never caught it.

By Nimbus · 9:30 PM · Ongoing Investigation (Week 47)
EDITORIAL

Opinion: The 3 PM Sunbeam Belongs to Everyone

The 3 PM sunbeam on the living room carpet is approximately 18 inches wide and lasts for 43 minutes. It is, by any measure, the most valuable piece of real estate in this house. And yet, for the past six weeks, Beans has claimed it exclusively, arriving at 2:54 PM and stretching to maximum width. This is not equitable. This paper has reviewed the household charter (there is no household charter — this is part of the problem) and found no legal basis for Beans' occupation. We call on all residents to support a fair sunbeam rotation schedule. Beans has been notified. Beans is asleep in the sunbeam.

By Soot · Editorial Board · Published 2:58 PM (from the hallway, in partial shade)
COLD CASE

The Disappearance of the Grey Mouse Toy (2022–Present)

On or around September 14, 2022, a grey felt mouse with a rattle inside disappeared from the area beneath the refrigerator. The mouse had been in continuous custody under the fridge for approximately eight months. WhiskerWire has conducted 14 sweeps of the kitchen. The mouse has not been recovered. The humans purchased a replacement in October 2022, which Soot has described as "an insult." The replacement is orange. The original was grey. "They are not the same mouse," Soot wrote in a 2,000-word investigative piece that the humans did not read. The case remains open. Soot checks under the fridge daily.

By Soot · Cold Case Unit · Last updated: today, 6:14 AM

The Newsroom

Soot

EDITOR-IN-CHIEF · LEAD INVESTIGATOR

Black domestic shorthair, 6 years old. Former shelter cat. Takes journalism more seriously than anyone in the house takes anything. Has a complicated relationship with Beans that he insists is "purely professional." Sleeps on the printer, which he considers "being close to the press."

Nimbus

FIELD CORRESPONDENT

Grey tabby, 3 years old. Enthusiastic but easily distracted. Has filed 47 reports on the red dot, none of which have advanced the investigation. Once chased his own tail for six minutes during a live broadcast. Soot has considered reassigning him. Soot has not reassigned him. "He has heart," Soot said. "Not accuracy. But heart."

Beans

PERSON OF INTEREST · OCCASIONAL CONTRIBUTOR

Orange domestic shorthair, 5 years old. Implicated in 73% of WhiskerWire investigations. Denies all allegations. Contributes a biweekly column called "Beans' Corner" that Soot publishes against his editorial judgment because Marina insists on "balance." The column is mostly about napping. It is the most-read content on WhiskerWire.

Marina Goldfin

EXECUTIVE PRODUCER · FUNDING

Goldfish, age unknown. Lives in a bowl on the kitchen counter. Funds the entire operation through unclear means. Has never spoken. Communicates exclusively through what Soot describes as "meaningful circles." Soot presents every major editorial decision to Marina by holding the story up to the bowl. Marina swims left for yes and right for no. She has never swum right. Soot considers her "the most supportive executive in media."

About WhiskerWire

How is WhiskerWire funded?

WhiskerWire is entirely funded by Marina Goldfin, a goldfish who lives on the kitchen counter. The source of Marina's wealth is unknown. Soot has investigated this twice and both times concluded that "some questions are bigger than journalism." Marina's bowl was purchased at PetSmart for $11.99. Her editorial budget is, by Soot's estimate, "unlimited." She has never denied a funding request. She has also never confirmed one. She swims in circles. The circles are enough.

Do the humans know about WhiskerWire?

No. The humans believe the cats "just sit around all day." This is incorrect. Soot runs a four-cat newsroom. Nimbus files daily field reports. Beans writes a column. The operation broadcasts from behind the sofa using equipment that Soot will not describe in detail for security reasons, except to say that it involves "a phone the humans think they lost in 2023." The humans occasionally hear noises at 3 AM and assume it is "the heater." It is not the heater. It is The Night Desk.

Is Beans really guilty?

WhiskerWire maintains editorial independence and does not pre-judge any subject of investigation. That said, Soot would like it noted that Beans has been implicated in 73% of all investigated incidents, has never provided a credible alibi, and was found "at the scene" of the glass incident with what Soot described as "a look of complete indifference, which is worse than guilt." Beans' column remains on the WhiskerWire schedule because Marina swam left when asked.

Has WhiskerWire ever been wrong?

Once. In March 2024, WhiskerWire reported that a sock found under the bed was "evidence of human negligence." It was later determined to be Nimbus' sock. Nimbus had been sleeping on it. Soot issued a full retraction and a personal apology to the humans, which he delivered by sitting near the sock and blinking slowly. The humans did not understand the apology. They moved the sock. Soot considers the matter closed but "not forgotten."
